oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Early view of the construction site for the Tennessee School for the Deaf

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Schools; Building construction; Forests
Tennessee School for the Deaf; Deaf -- Education -- Tennessee; Building trades
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The grounds of the Tennessee School for the Deaf early into the construction of the facilities. The landscape is largely wooded and a few construction elements can be seen. One larger site is on the right along with various construction supplies. A dirt path leads toward the center of the landscape. A small shed is visible on the left.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Marr and Holman, Architects (Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Marr and Holman Architectural Firm Records, 1911-1929
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Tennessee School for the Deaf is a state-operated K-12 residential and day school for the deaf and hard of hearing established in 1844. Its current campus in the historic Island Park area of Knoxville was designed in 1928 by Thomas S. Marr, who was also deaf. Marr & Holman was a highly-acclaimed architectural firm from Nashville known for its traditional and art deco designs. They designed numerous buildings including the Nashville Post Office and the baseball grandstand at Sulphur Dell Park.
